title: TomPegden published Unemployment down as job opportunities rise
text:
Unemployment down as job opportunities rise By TomPegden | Posted: July 20, 2016 0 COMMENTS SHARES Brexit anxiety yet to hit jobs market Unemployment down as job opportunities rise X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
New claimant figures suggest anxiety over Brexit has yet to have any impact on the jobs market. 
Both Jobcentre Plus and the regional Chamber of Commerce said there was still plenty of work out there despite concerns within the business sector over leaving the EU. 
New figures released today show the number of people claiming Jobseeker's Allowance and Universal Credit in Leicestershire continued to drop. 
National figures from the Office of National Statistics show the UK unemployment rate at 4.9 per cent – the lowest since July 2005. Related content Company Car Woman Cherie Concannon 
The national unemployment total fell to 1.65 million in the March-to-May period, down 54,000 from the previous three months. 
Roger Matthews, senior operations leader for Jobcentre Plus for Leicester, based in New Walk, said claimants were currently able to walk into the county's job centres and walk out with work. 
He said: "It's still very positive at the moment, and there has been a continued downward trend in claimants. 
"A lot of positive work is going on in job centres with a lot of vacancies. 
"The labour market is still very buoyant, with more employers and agencies coming in and holding daily job clubs and we are running weekly job fairs in the city centre and people are leaving our offices with jobs. 
"We have Christmas recruitment on the horizon and nothing to suggest any changes in the short term." 
Mr Matthews said the number of claimants in the city was 4,370 in May – 20 per cent down on the same month last year when it was 5,470, and 1 per cent down on a month earlier. 
He said the number of young claimants within the city – aged 18-24 – were also down 20 per cent year-on-year at 825 in May, and also down 2 per cent on April. 
The number of claimants aged over 50 was 13 per cent down year-on-year at 1,005.In the wider county, overall claimants in May were down 9.4 per cent over the year at 3,380, and down 2.9 per cent on the previous month. 
The region's unemployment rate remains at 4.5 per cent, below the national average. 
Scott Knowles, chief executive of East Midlands Chamber of Commerce, said: "The latest employment figures for the region are once again positive and demonstrate just how resilient local businesses were in spite of all the uncertainty created by the EU referendum. 
"It will be interesting to see what next month's figures bring, given the collapse of Government immediately after the outcome of the vote became known and which caused the prophecies of financial doom and gloom to become self-fulfilling. 
"It is of paramount importance that Prime Minister Theresa May and her newly-formed Government now focus on the big decisions which will need to be made to get Britain back to business, including finance for investment, skills provision and the delivery of first class digital and transport infrastructure. 
"They also need to demonstrate strong leadership as the negotiations about the UK's future with Europe progress and we determine our place in the global marketplace during – and after – Brexit."
